children.name: nervous
children.definition: /ˈnɜːʳvəs/ lo lắng
examples: ▪ Bill looked nervous, and I could see his hands were shaking.
nervous about
lo lắng về
▪ Kelli was so nervous about her exam that she couldn’t sleep.
▪ I’m a little nervous about leaving the kids at home all alone.
▪ Many investors are nervous about their investments after the recent drop in the stock market.
make somebody nervous
làm ai đólo lắng
▪ It makes me nervous when you drive that fast.
nervously[adverb]
một cách lo lắng
▪ He was pacing nervously up and down the room.
nervousness[uncountable noun]
nỗi lo lắng
▪ She tried to hide her nervousness, but it was clear she wasn’t comfortable making the speech.

children.name: tense
children.definition: /tens/  so worried about something that you cannot relax, and you easily get angry or upset:căng thẳng
examples: ▪ I always feel tense after driving all day.
▪ Mary’s problems at work were making her tense and irritable.
▪ You seem awfully tense - why don’t you have a drink and try to relax?
tensely[adverb]một cách căng thẳng
▪ Everyone waited tensely for the winner’s name to be announced.

children.name: jumpy/jittery
children.definition: /ˈdʒʌmpi, ˈdʒɪtəri/  very nervous so that you are unable to relax and are easily surprised by sudden sounds or movements:hay giật mình
examples: ▪ The dogs are jumpy tonight - I wonder if there’s something outside.
▪ She was getting jumpy thinking about the trip.
▪ I was feeling extremely jittery - all I wanted was to leave the bar as quickly as possible.
▪ Investors are jittery due to uncertainty about interest rates.

children.name: on edge
children.definition: /ɒn ˈedʒ/  if someone is on edge or if their nerves are on edge, they are nervous and likely to become angry or upset very easily:bực mình, dễ cáu
examples: ▪ Jerry had had a hard day and his nerves were on edge.
▪ As reports of robberies continued to appear in the press, the whole community was increasingly on edge.

children.name: uneasy
children.definition: /ʌnˈiːzi/  nervous that something bad might happen, so that you feel anxious and unable to relax until the danger has passed:lo lắng, băn khoăn
examples: ▪ There’s something I don’t trust about him. He makes me feel very uneasy.
▪ It was the same uneasy feeling he’d experienced that morning when he saw the police car outside.
uneasy about
lo lắng, băn khoăn về
▪ Rebecca was already beginning to feel uneasy about accepting the stranger’s offer of a ride.
uneasily[adverb]
lo lắng, băn khoăn
▪ Boyd glanced around uneasily. ‘Do you think anyone is watching us?’
uneasiness[uncountable noun]
sự lo lắng, băn khoăn
▪ She looked at the clock with growing uneasiness - he was already two hours late.

children.name: panicky
children.definition: /ˈpænɪki/  very nervous and anxious about something, especially when you are in a dangerous situation that you cannot control or change:hốt hoảng
examples: ▪ I began to feel panicky, sure that I was going to miss the train.
▪ ‘Is he really dead?’ Abe asked in a panicky voice.
▪ After waiting for him for two hours, Lorna got panicky and called the police.

children.name: have butterflies
children.definition: /hæv ˈbʌtəʳflaɪz/  informal to feel nervous about doing something that you are going to do very soon because it is important and you want to do it well:lo lắng, bồn chồn
examples: ▪ Some actors never have butterflies before going on stage.
have butterflies in your stomach
lo lắng, sốt ruột
▪ It was the morning of the World Cup Final and most of the players had butterflies in their stomachs.

children.name: be a nervous wreck
children.definition: /biː ə ˌnɜːʳvəs ˈrek/  if someone is a nervous wreck, they have been made so nervous that they have completely lost all their confidence and their ability to remain calm or think sensibly:
examples: cực kỳ lo lắng
▪ Before the plane took off she was a nervous wreck - she had to be strapped into her seat.
▪ Even though I’d been practicing for months, by the day of the competition I was a nervous wreck.
wrecknoun[ C ]người suy nhược; người tàn phế
informalsomeone who is in bad physical or mental condition
_The stress she had been under at work reduced her to anervous/quiveringwreck.

children.name: be a bundle of nerves
children.definition: /biː ə ˌbʌndl əv ˈnɜːʳvz/  informal to be so nervous that you are shaking and you find it impossible to behave calmly, especially for a long time:lo âu khắc khoải
examples: ▪ Since she lost her job Rosie’s been a bundle of nerves.
▪ Harry was a bundle of nerves the whole time his wife was in the hospital.

children.name: sb who is often or always nervous
nervous
children.definition: /ˈnɜːʳvəs/  someone who is often or always worried and frightened that something unpleasant may happen:hay lo lắng
examples: ▪ She’s such a nervous child we don’t like to leave her on her own.
▪ Mr Darby was a mild, nervous man who seemed to expect people to ignore him.

children.name: highly-strung
children.definition: British /high-strung American /ˌhaɪli ˈstrʌŋ◂, ˌhaɪ ˈstrʌŋ◂/  always nervous and unable to relax, especially so that you react in a very extreme way to ordinary situations:hết sức căng thẳng, hết sức nhạy cảm
examples: ▪ Mark’s a little high-strung, so go easy on him.
▪ Her main problem is that she is very highly-strung which tends to make other people feel nervous too.

children.name: uptight
children.definition: /ʌpˈtaɪt/  informal unable to be relaxed about life in general, so that this makes you seem unfriendly and unhappy:bồn chồn, lo lắng, căng thẳng
examples: ▪ He tries to be kind, but he always seems a little uptight.
▪ She’s one of those narrow-minded, uptight people who think that for a work of art to be great it can’t be pleasurable.

children.name: nerves
children.definition: /nɜːʳvz/  the feeling of being nervous because you are worried or a little frightened about something, especially if this feeling is likely to affect your behaviour or performance:Trạng thái thần kinh kích động
examples: ▪ Normally she’s very relaxed and amusing. It must be nerves.
a case/attack of nerves
Bị bệnh dễ kích động
▪ She had a sudden attack of nerves and refused to go to see the dentist.
calm/steady etc your nerves try to relax
thư giãn thần kinh
▪ Arnie had a drink before the meeting to steady his nerves.
suffer from nerves British
bị kích động
▪ Although a competent teacher, he suffers from nerves when the students behave badly.

children.name: tension
children.definition: /ˈtenʃən/  a feeling of being nervous and unable to relax, especially before something is about to happen:sự căng thẳng
examples: ▪ Her voice trembled with tension.
tension is high
căng thẳng tăng cao
people feel very nervous
▪ The tension was high in Mexico as the day of the decision approached.
tension mounts
căng thẳng leo thang
people feel more and more nervous
▪ A crowd gathered and tension mounted till the riot broke out.

children.name: a situation in which people feel nervous
tense
children.definition: /tens/  a tense situation makes people feel nervous and anxious, especially because they are worried about what might happen next or what someone might do:căng thẳng
examples: ▪ There was a tense silence, and then everyone began to laugh.
▪ The negotiations became increasingly tense as the weeks went by.
▪ The journey through the mountains went well even though there were a few tense moments when the car skidded.
▪ When someone mentioned Andy’s time in prison, the atmosphere grew tense.

children.name: strained
children.definition: /streɪnd/  a situation that is strained makes people feel nervous, embarrassed, and uncomfortable, and unable to behave naturally:căng thẳng, gượng ép
examples: ▪ After the argument there was a strained silence.
▪ Since my father’s affair things have been very strained between him and my mother.
▪ The strained atmosphere at the dinner made it difficult to chat with people.

children.name: uneasy
children.definition: /ʌnˈiːzi/  a situation that is uneasy makes people feel a little nervous because they are uncertain about what will happen next or what someone might do:không thoải mái
examples: ▪ After the speech there was an uneasy silence and nobody clapped.
▪ Since the two sides declared a ceasefire, there has been an uneasy calm throughout the region.

children.name: unsettling
children.definition: /ʌnˈsetlɪŋ/  an unsettling situation makes you feel slightly nervous and unable to relax or concentrate completely:đáng lo
examples: ▪ The weather forecast was unsettling - we had nowhere to go if a really big storm hit.
▪ Greenspan delivered more unsettling news about the economy the next day.

children.name: nailbiting
children.definition: /ˈneɪlbaɪtɪŋ/  a nailbiting situation is so exciting that it makes you nervous, especially because you are waiting for a result or decision:căng thẳng, gay cấn
examples: ▪ Waiting to become a father is one of the most nailbiting situations a man can face.
nailbiting finish
kết thúc đầy gây cấn
▪ With three minutes left, the World Cup Final is set for a nailbiting finish.

children.name: nerve-wracking
children.definition: /ˈnɜːʳv ˌrækɪŋ/  a nerve-wracking situation makes you feel very nervous because it is difficult or frightening:căng não
examples: ▪ Your first appearance on stage is always a nerve-wracking experience
▪ Trying to keep track of all those little kids at the same time must be pretty nerve-wracking.

children.name: charged
children.definition: /tʃɑːʳdʒd/  a charged situation or subject makes people feel very nervous and is likely to cause arguments or violence:gây búc xúc
examples: ▪ Abortion is still a very emotionally charged issue in the U.S.
highly charged
đầy căng thẳng
▪ In a highly charged press conference, Armstrong defended his attack on the children.
charged atmosphere
tình hình căng thẳng
▪ The already charged atmosphere erupted into violence when police told the crowd to disperse.

children.name: make sb nervous
children.definition: make somebody nervous/ˌmeɪk somebody ˈnɜːʳvəs/
examples: khiến ai đó lo lắng
▪ Have you seen the way he looks at people? He makes me nervous.
▪ Don’t watch me while I’m typing - it makes me really nervous.
▪ Thunder and lightning always make the horses nervous.

children.name: unsettle
children.definition: /ʌnˈsetl/  if something unsettles you, it makes you feel slightly nervous and unable to relax or concentrate completely:làm rối loạn
examples: ▪ Ted’s angry outbursts unsettled the whole family.
▪ The threat of war has been enough to unsettle international oil traders.
▪ She was still recovering from the accident so he avoided any subjects which might unsettle her.

children.name: unnerve
children.definition: /ˌʌnˈnɜːʳv/  to make someone very nervous, especially by shocking or surprising them:làm ai đó cực kỳ lo lắng
examples: ▪ Moore had been extremely unnerved by the FBI’s visit.
▪ The daily news stories of the worsening economy unnerved the nation.
unnerving[adjective]căng thẳng
▪ a bizarre and unnerving crime

children.name: psych out
children.definition: /ˌsaɪk ˈaʊt/  to try to make someone, especially someone you are competing against in a game, lose their confidence and their ability to remain calm:tác động tâm lý
examples: psych out somebody
tác động tâm lý ai đó
▪ McEnroe often used his bad behaviour in difficult tennis matches to psych out his opponent.
psych somebody out
tác động tâm lý ai đó
▪ Whenever we play chess Bill tries to psych me out by smirking every time I make a move.

children.name: put sb on edge
children.definition: put somebody on edge/ˌpʊt somebody ɒn ˈedʒ/  to make someone feel very nervous so that they cannot relax:khiến ai đó căng thẳng
examples: ▪ Trying to keep the plan a secret put us all on edge.
▪ Layoffs and work upheavals have put many employees on edge, both at work and at home.
